bibl.title: Letter from Atcheson Laughlin Hench to Philip Showalter Hench, October 24, 1940

div1.p: Atcheson Hench details the dinner given in honor of Moran.

div1.head: Letter from Atcheson Laughlin Hench to Philip Showalter Hench, October 24, 1940
div1.p:
My best wishes for a most happy
occasion tomorrow and Saturday. Please send me a
copy of your speech at the banquet Saturday night.

We had a quiet but delightful banquet up at
Inky Beauchamp's to Mr. Moran. Jordan gave me a seat
beside him and he and I had a delightful time talking all
through the dinner. He told me lots about himself and about
your visit and work and Mary's good sportsmanship in
just letting you hunt and hunt on till you had exhausted
the subject or yourself or both.

After dinner Jordan spoke first, briefly, of our guest
and his achievement. Then he introduced General Keane
who told the whole story, right from Agramonte down, of the
yellow-fever study, putting Lazear, Finley (?), Walter Reed,
Kissinger & Moran in their historical places; and telling of your studies.
I guess he spent nearly fifty minutes telling all this.

Then Jordan said than though Mr. Moran made no speeches,
he would answer questions. Several questions got him going
and I guess he talked 30 or 40 minutes. Anyway he said
“I think I've talked longer here than at any meeting before in
my life.”

I have full notes of the whole meeting and will make
a transcript for you in the next few days.

Here are two newspaper items. Let me know if you want
more copies.
Best wishes & congratulations ; & love to mother too.
div1.closer:
Atch. Over
Dr. Cooke, of Lexington, couldn't come. But General Keane explained
his part in the study.
